Summary: Agent A is right that the code can read past the end of the header value: MHD_lookup_connection_value_n may return pos->value without guaranteeing it is NUL‑terminated when the caller does not request the length, and MHD_str_equal_caseless_ walks its first argument until a '\0'. That combination can lead to an out‑of‑bounds read at runtime. However, this is not a direct violation of MISRA C:2023 Rule 21.17 as quoted, because 21.17 explicitly concerns the use of the string handling functions from <string.h> (memcpy, strlen, strcpy, etc.). MHD_str_equal_caseless_ is a project-local function, not a <string.h> function, so flagging this code under Rule 21.17 is a misapplication of that specific rule. In short: the reported runtime defect is real and should be fixed (request the length and/or use a length‑bounded comparison), but the claim that it violates Rule 21.17 exactly is incorrect.

Recommended fix: call MHD_lookup_connection_value_n requesting the value length (pass a size_t pointer) when obtaining enc, then use a length‑bounded comparison (or copy and NUL‑terminate) instead of MHD_str_equal_caseless_.
